intro: Sidalcea hirtipes, commonly known as the hairy checker-mallow, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is often found in open woodlands and grasslands. Its showy, pink to purple flowers bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators like bees and butterflies. The hairy texture of its stems and leaves is a distinguishing botanical feature.
